competencyText.en-us: Grade 6-8
Administrative Support
Demonstrate an understanding of the administrative support career pathway.
Define and use proper terminology associated with the administrative support career pathway.
Describe some of the careers available in the administrative support career pathway.
Identify common characteristics of the careers in the administrative support career pathway.
Research the history of the administrative support career pathway and describe how the careers have evolved and impacted society.
Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the administrative support career pathway.
Describe technologies associated in careers within the administrative support career pathway.

Identify skills required to successfully enter a career in the general management career pathway.

Supplemental
Identify and understand computer hardware.
Define and identify input, output, and storage devices and their functions.
Define and identify memory in a computer.
Identify information technology tools and their proper uses.
Define and identify various software applications (word processing, spreadsheets, database, presentation, digital publishing) and their uses.
Identify the functions of web browsers, and use them to access the World Wide Web and other computer resources.
Use different web search engines effectively to locate information.
Understand how email clients send simple messages and files to other internet users.
Develop and apply keyboarding skills.
Demonstrate proper alphanumeric keyboarding techniques using correct ergonomic habits.
Demonstrate safety and respect for equipment and materials in lab.
Demonstrate proper techniques for alphanumeric keyboarding while keeping fingers on home row keys.
Demonstrate speed building using techniques for numeric and symbol keyboarding.
Develop and apply word processing skills.
Start and exit word processing software.
Identify the parts of a word processing screen, e.g., ribbon, status bar, title bar, insertion point, scroll box and bar, and tabs.
Demonstrate ability to use the word processing window, including menus, toolbars, dialog boxes, tabs and ribbons.
Create and edit a new document.
Understand different views of document and using the zoom function.
Identify methods of moving the insertion point.
Select and edit text.
Move text in a document using the copy, cut, and paste and drag and drop text commands.
Format text by changing the font, size, color.
Align text horizontally and vertically.
Utilize the Undo and Redo commands.
Utilize the Show/Hide command.
Use basic proofreading skills including proofreader’s marks.
Use spell check, grammar check and thesaurus programs properly.
Understand the difference between Save and Save As.
Save, open and replace files.
Utilize Print Preview and demonstrate printing capabilities.
Demonstrate efficient use of the Help program.
Create and format memos.
Create and format business letters using the block and modified block style.
Create and format one-page academic and business reports using Modern Language Association (MLA) style.
Identify how to address and print envelopes.
Insert a hyperlink into a document.
Understand and use read-only documents.
Insert page breaks in a multi-page document.
Format columns within a document.
Work with document templates.
Open and work with multiple documents.
Apply different views to a document.
Apply tabs, line spacing and paragraph indents.
Format text.
Apply styles in a document.
Use find and replace.
Utilize the format painter.
Highlight text.
Insert date and time.
Insert and manipulate graphics, word art and text boxes.
Insert and remove a manual page break in a document.
Create bulleted and numbered lists.
Insert, move, and enter data in a table.
Insert, delete, and merge columns, rows, and cells.
Change column or row width and height.
Align table on page.
Apply cell content alignment.
Change table styles and apply borders and shading.
Set margins, page orientation, and page size.
Insert a watermark, apply a page border, and change the background color.
Create headers and footers in a document.
Save a document.
Save a document in various formats.
Understand printing options.
Describe the general functions and applications of word processing software.
Define and explain the benefits of cloud computing.
List and describe common word processor tools and features.
Identify and explain the benefits of common keyboard shortcuts used in word processing.
Format the page setup of a document.
Explain advanced printing options in word processing.
Copy, paste and move text within a document using mouse, menu and keyboard techniques.
Copy, paste and move text among multiple documents using mouse, menu and keyboard techniques.
Modify document view settings to display close-up, single and multiple pages.
Define format as it relates to word processing.
Format text using styles and font tools.
Format a document using multi-level heading styles to enable an outline view (e.g. document map, navigation pane) in word processing.
Create a table of contents using auto-generation tools and techniques in word processing.
Insert page breaks in a document.
Create source citations and a bibliography in a document.
Use word processing tools to determine the number of pages, words and characters in a document.
Use spell check, grammar check, thesaurus, and find & replace to edit a document.
Insert and modify sizing of images in a word processing document.
Position an image relative to text in a document, using various text-wrapping options.
Use word processing drawing tools to create pre-formatted shapes that enhance a document’s content.
Use illustration tools to create a visual representation of information.
Apply a column layout to text in a document as appropriate for the content (e.g., article, newsletter).
Apply simple numbered and bulleted lists in a document.
Define a new multilevel list.
Use a brochure and flyer template.
Convert a body of text into a table structure in a document.
Define collaboration and explain ways that users can collaborate.
Use the translation tool in a word processor to translate text in a document.
Add comments to a document when reviewing and editing content.
Revise a document using editing tools in word processing, and accept or reject changes.
Demonstrate proficiency in using presentation software.
Start and exit presentation software.
Identify the parts of a presentation screen.
Create a new presentation document.
Select design layout, background, a template and color scheme.
Edit text.
Format text and graphics.
Select order of frames.
Demonstrate the ability to print presentations using different settings.
Spell check a presentation.
Apply fill effects. Insert lines and shapes.
Order, group, and rotate objects.
Animate graphics.
Apply slide transitions and timings.
Incorporate transitions on text, tables, charts, and graphics.
Add sound.
Apply action buttons.
Insert a hyperlink.
Rearrange slide order through slide sorter.
Add notes to a presentation.
Customize timing and rehearsing to coordinate with oral presentation.
Save a presentation in various formats.
Demonstrate presentation skills.
Describe presentation software and the ways it can be used.
Create and modify a slide master.
Add and format titles, subtitles and talking points in presentation slides.
Add slide numbers, date, and time to presentation slides.
Insert and format images and graphics in presentation slides.
Insert new or duplicate slides in a presentation.
Modify slide transitions in a presentation to include animation.
Insert and modify sound settings and timing in a presentation.
Modify the sequence of slides in a presentation.
Produce a presentation that includes text, graphics and images, and present it.
Set up slideshow to repeat the presentation.
Develop and apply spreadsheet skills.
Insert and delete rows and columns.
Clear and delete data.
Copy and move data.
Fill the same data in adjacent cells.
Fill data series in adjacent cells.
Hide and Unhide columns and rows.
Freeze and Unfreeze columns and rows.
Sort data.
Print the worksheet, with and without grids.
Create a chart.
Apply cell borders and shading.
Add a header and footer.
Rotate text in a cell.
Create a formula using mathematical operations.

Create a formula finding maximum, minimum and average.
Format a chart changing the font size, component colors and rotation of charts for graphical emphasis.
Insert a picture in a worksheet.

Create a new worksheet.
Resize column width and row height in a spreadsheet.
Format the contents of a cell, i.e., change fonts and font sizes, align text, and format numbers.
Merge cells.
Use Undo and Redo commands.
AutoFormat the worksheet.
Use the AutoSum feature.
Define spreadsheet and describe ways it may be used.
Identify the parts of the spreadsheet display, including cells, columns and rows, cell references, cell range.
Create and navigate through multiple spreadsheets in a file.
Insert and format various types of data (text, numeric, date/time) in a spreadsheet cell.
Select multiple cells, including adjacent and non-adjacent ranges, using mouse and keyboard techniques.
Cut, copy, and paste information from one or more cells to another part of the spreadsheet.
Apply and modify cell formatting for currency, date and percentage values.
Describe the purpose of a table and how it relates to a spreadsheet.
Create and print a table and/or range that displays and sums the values of different data types.
Identify and explain when to use various types of charts and common chart components.
Insert common functions and simple mathematical formulas into a spreadsheet.
Distinguish between absolute and relative cell references in a spreadsheet.
Use the sort function to organize information numerically or alphabetically, including multiple levels of sorting.
Use the filter function to display spreadsheet data based on specific criteria.
Use conditional formatting.
Develop and utilize business-related skills.
Identify good grooming and dress habits for the workplace.
Demonstrate problem solving skills.
Apply teamwork in the classroom.
Identify the importance of impromptu speaking ability in the workplace.
Identify the importance of prepared speaking ability in the workplace.
Compare grooming and dress standards in various workplace environments.
Perform an impromptu and a prepared presentation.
Prepare a resume and cover letter.
Prepare a thank you letter to a potential employer.
Discuss job searching skills.
Identify employment benefits.
Understand labor laws.
Understand appropriate procedures for changing jobs.
Complete a job application.
Demonstrate skills and appropriate attire necessary for a successful job interview.
Understand the importance of a positive attitude in obtaining and maintaining a job.
Understand the importance of proper grooming and appearance for the workplace.
Utilize brainstorming techniques to solve a problem.
Research sources of employment.
Discuss employer expectations toward prospective and current employees.
Discuss the value of updating technology skills as the workplace environment changes.
Prepare a list of strategies for communicating in multicultural settings.
Analyze the importance of good work habits for success in the workplace.
Evaluate a quality completed job application.
Identify characteristics of ethical behavior in the workplace.
Understand the importance of personal integrity in the workplace.
Develop an understanding of the transferrable skills for school to work.
Demonstrate teamwork.
Make an impromptu presentation.
Make a prepared presentation.
Collaborate and present as a team.
Develop problem-solving skills.
Perform activities using the world wide web.
Explore the history of the Internet.
Identify and define internet vocabulary such as hyperlink, WWW, URL, and web browser.
Identify basic principles of the Domain Name System (DNS).
Perform basic internet searches.
Identify and use various web browsers.
Identify and use various search engines.
Evaluate websites.
Understand Favorites and Bookmarks.
Understand and demonstrate internet safety.
Discuss internet privacy, ethics, network etiquette and copyright laws.
Download files.
Download graphics.
Perform advanced searches using Boolean operators.
Discuss email, email attachment, address book, and calendar.
Discuss instant messaging.
Copy and paste from browser to other applications.
Develop and apply digital design skills utilizing current technology.
Demonstrate ability to launch digital design software.
Create a new document from a template (e.g. newsletter, brochure, greeting card, letterhead, or flyer).

Apply design layout and color scheme.
Apply styles and borders.
Insert a text box, word art and graphics.
Apply formatting to a text box, word art and graphics.
Edit text and layouts.
Demonstrate the ability to spell check, save, and print a document.
Apply special formatting (e.g. add gradient, text wrapping, positioning).
Insert graphics from files.
Create new document without using templates.
Save a graphic to file.
Demonstrate proficiency in advanced print layout options.
Demonstrate knowledge, skill, and application of information systems to accomplish job objectives and enhance workplace performance.
Use current and emerging computer technology and software to perform personal and business related tasks.
Apply the use of information management tools to develop and coordinate the distribution of work.
Develop keyboarding skills to enter and manipulate text and data.
Identify and describe communications and networking systems used in workplace environments.
Use reference materials such as on-line help, vendor bulletin boards, tutorials, and manuals available for application software.
Describe ethical issues and problems associated with computers and information systems.
Develop an awareness of business organizational structures.
Explore organizational structures in today’s business environments.
Assess personal performance and identify strategies for improvement.
Develop an awareness of the impact of the economy as it relates to the marketplace.
Assess personal strengths as they relate to business career exploration.
Survey and assess personal aptitudes and interests related to careers.
Apply mathematical strategies to business applications.
Select and implement appropriate mathematical tools to solve business financial problems.
Identify information technology tools and their purposes.
Define and identify various software applications (word processing, spreadsheets, database, presentation, digital publishing) and their uses.
Identify the functions of web browsers, and use them to access the World Wide Web and other computer resources typically used in the Business, Management and Administration career cluster.
Use different types of web search engines effectively to locate information relevant to the Business, Management and Administration career cluster.
Demonstrate proficiency using the Internet to locate information.
Identify and use web terminology.
Define Universal Resource Locators (URLs) and associated protocols.
Compare and contrast the types of internet domains.
Demonstrate proficiency using search engines, including Boolean search techniques.
Demonstrate proficiency using various web tools (e.g., downloading of files, transfer of files, telnet, PDF).
Compare and contrast the roles of web servers and web browsers.
Evaluate online information for relevance, credibility and quality using basic guidelines and indicators (e.g. authority, affiliation, purpose, bias, date).
Identify and apply copyright and fair use guidelines, and explain plagiarism as an ethical and legal violation.
Incorporate results from internet searches into a research project (e.g., report, summary).
Download images as needed to support a research project, complying with copyright notices.
Properly cite internet sources used to obtain information for a research project.
Identify and explore careers in the Business Management & Administration cluster.

List the skills, abilities, and talents needed for careers in the Business Management & Administration career cluster.
Identify the level of training and education required for careers in the Business Management & Administration career cluster.

Apply math, science, and reading skills in the completion of a project or activity related to the Business Management & Administration career cluster.

Identify and describe web terminology.

Demonstrate proficiency in using graphics software.
Describe graphics software and its uses.

Demonstrate knowledge of safety and privacy practices for online communication.
Define privacy as it relates to digital footprint.
Describe the risks of communicating on social networking sites and identify ways to communicate safely.

Describe online communication practices that contribute to cyberbullying.
Practice safe online communication techniques with internet searches, email, and other social network web sites.
Follow an Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) when accessing the Internet.
Demonstrate an understanding of internet safety and ethics.
Distinguish between viruses and malware and discuss their impact on personal privacy and computer operation.
Adhere to cyber safety practices with regard to conducting internet searches, email, chat rooms, and other social network websites.
Adhere to Acceptable Use Policies when accessing the Internet.
Describe risks associated with social networking sites and ways to mitigate these risks.
Define privacy and relate it to the term digital footprint.
Practice cybersafety techniques to protect your personal information when using internet searches, email, chat rooms, and social network websites.
Describe cyberbullying, its impact on perpetrators and victims and ways to respond.
Describe risks associated with sexting (including legal issues, social consequences), and discuss methods for response, reporting, and prevention.
Describe the risks associated with online gaming and ways to mitigate these risks.
Describe the ethics and copyright legalities of downloading music or videos from the Internet.
Compare and contrast rules for copyright and fair use, especially in relation to using online resources for school and educational purposes.
Differentiate between viruses and malware, specifically their sources, ploys, and impact on personal privacy and computer operation, and ways to avoid infection.

Perform an antivirus scan on a computer system to check for viruses and malware.
Describe strong password practices.
Practice cyber safety techniques to protect a computer system when using internet searches, email and social network websites.
Identify security issues related to mobile phones, including personal information compromised if a phone is lost or stolen.
